description:
It was hardly a sure fire bet, a series of 1960 stories, a musical, televised adaptation with puppets and later an animated version, strip cartoon, Gene Kelly's Singing In The Rain tribute, a biography, Royal Mail stamp, Marmite ads and app, naturally. You might think, what was left to do? Well, with me in the studio are the writer and director Paul King and the producer David Heyman, whose other box office hits include Harry Potter series and Gravity. Making Paddington, Michael Bond's inspiration, that first novel in the late 50s, by the time it's really successful, people are still remembering the war. I mean, it's still, I was brought up reading them in the 60s and people still talked about the war. That very much infuses those books, that sense of recent events. You had to present it afresh for a new generation, was that the consideration?

"Well, we were certainly interested in the sort of overtones of evacuees that there are with Paddington, sort of standing, flown at a station with a label around its neck or sitting on a suitcase. We were sort of aware that, well, that image is probably quite familiar in Britain. I just thought most children have studied evacuees at some points at school, it might not be so familiar around the world. So we were kind of keen to present it afresh. And it feels like it's the great challenge of the Birkis. Here is an orphan, a sort of refugee."
